title: Brexit latest: As MPs defy Boris Johnson, is Brexit still happening?
text:
MPs have voted for the Letwin amendment in Parliament, which seeks to avoid a no-deal Brexit on October 31 (Picture: House of Commons/PA Wire)

The Brexit deal proposed by Boris Johnson for October 31 has been, for the time being, thwarted by MPs in Parliament on one of the most memorable days in British political history.

After the Prime Minister made his case in front of the Conservative and Labour benches and the rest of the house, the House of Commons voted 322-306 to amend the Government’s Brexit motion and mandate a Brexit delay.

Johnson had returned to Westminster with an air of triumph after seemingly agreeing a long-awaited deal in Brussels at the end of the week, but he has not been able to secure the vote result that could have sealed the Withdrawal Agreement today.

So what does this mean for Brexit and is the country’s departure from the EU still going ahead? Read on to discover what we know after a dramatic day…

Is Brexit still happening?

As a deal has not been agreed by the House of Commons today, Johnson is legally obliged to send a letter to Brussels before 11pm requesting that Article 50, which initiates Britain’s withdrawal from the EU, is extended.

The Brexit deal he has negotiated could still go through, with many speculating that Parliament could be asked to vote again on Tuesday afternoon.

As many as a million people are thought to have marched outside Parliament in opposition to Brexit (Picture: EPA/FACUNDO ARRIZABALAGA)

The leader of the House of Commons, Jacob Rees-Mogg, has also suggested that the vote could be brought forward to Monday.

Today’s news makes it unlikely that Brexit will go through by the long-established date of October 31, although it could happen at a later date if a Parliamentary vote agrees to it.

The alternative is a second referendum, which as many as a million protestors have been calling for outside Parliament.

The Speaker of the House, John Bercow, said that he would rule on the matter on Monday.
